text.0: to the great hero him who sets his mind thereon and viṣṇu praise aloud in song your draught of juice.
text.1: gods neer beguiled who borne as twere by noble steed have stood upon the lofty ridges of the hills.
text.2: your somadrinker keeps afar your furious rush indra and viṣṇu when ye come with all your might.
text.3: that which hath been directed well at mortal man bowarmed kṛśānus arrow ye turn far aside.
text.4: these offerings increase his mighty manly strength he brings both parents down to share the genial flow.
text.5: he lowers though a son the fathers highest name the third is that which is high in the light of heaven.
text.6: we laud this manly power of him the mighty one preserver inoffensive bounteous and benign.
text.7: his who strode widely pacing with three steppings forth over the realms of earth for freedom and for life.
text.8: a mortal man when he beholds two steps of him who looks upon the light is restless with amaze.
text.9: but his third step doth no one venture to approach no nor the feathered birds of air who fly with wings.
text.10: he like a rounded wheel hath in swift motion set his ninety racing steeds together with the four.
text.11: developed vast in form with those who sing forth praise a youth no more a child he cometh to our call.
